item.title: On Color Palettes
item.description:
Bought a new book on color theory today. There’s something meditative about limiting yourself to five colors. Constraints breed creativity.

The book is Josef Albers’ “Interaction of Color.” Published in 1963, still relevant today. His core insight: we never see colors in isolation. Every hue is influenced by its neighbors.

Put a gray square on a yellow background and it looks purple. Put the same gray on a purple background and it looks yellow. The color itself hasn’t changed—only the context.

item.title: ImageMagick
item.description:
Discovered you can remap any image to a custom palette with one command. Feed it your colors, get back a perfectly matched image. The web in 1999 knew something we forgot.

The command is deceptively simple. You define a palette—four colors, maybe five—and ImageMagick does the rest. It finds the nearest match for every pixel, applies dithering to smooth the transitions, and spits out a file a fraction of the original size.
